Projected start date for a potential new NBA-style league in Europe, in talks between the NBA and FIBA.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The span from the opening of the NBA season to the end of the regular season, during which milestones, international player development, and potential new league formation will be key topics.

keyTakeAways: The NBA season opens with a record 135 players born outside the U.S., from 43 countries.
71 of these international players are from Europe — the highest number from that continent in NBA history.
Canada leads with 23 non-U.S. players, followed by France (19) and Australia (13).
The Atlanta Hawks open the season with 10 international players, tying an NBA record.
All 30 NBA teams have at least one international player on their opening night rosters.
The NBA and FIBA are in talks to launch a new league in Europe, potentially as early as 2027.

International-born players have won the last seven NBA MVP awards, including Nikola Jokic (Serbia), Giannis Antetokounmpo (Greece), Joel Embiid (Cameroon-born, U.S. citizen), and Shai Gilgeous-Alexander (Canada).
LeBron James is on track to reach 23 seasons in the NBA, tying Vince Carter for most seasons by a player, and is close to breaking career records in points, field goals, and minutes played.
The NBA is expected to finalize a new All-Star Game format featuring matchups between U.S. and international players.

The Brooklyn Nets are the youngest team in the league, with no players in the top 100 active scorers, and their combined career stats are below top players like LeBron James, Stephen Curry, and Russell Westbrook.
There are multiple players with the names Jordan, Nikola, and James — including seven players named Jordan and five named Nikola — highlighting naming trends in the league.
Orlando Robinson is the only player in the league to wear his first name on the front and last name on the back of his jersey.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The 2025 NBA season opens with a record number of international players — 135 born outside the U.S. from 43 countries, with 71 from Europe, the most ever from that continent. Canada leads with 23 players, followed by France and Australia. The Atlanta Hawks tie an NBA record with 10 international players on their roster. All 30 teams have at least one international player. The NBA and FIBA are in talks to launch a new European league as early as 2027, reflecting the global expansion of the sport. The last seven NBA MVPs have been awarded to players born outside the U.S., highlighting a shift in the league’s global talent pool. Key players such as Shai Gilgeous-Alexander (Canada), Nikola Jokic (Serbia), and Giannis Antetokounmpo (Greece) exemplify this trend. Meanwhile, the Brooklyn Nets are noted as one of the youngest teams with no players in the top 100 active scorers, while LeBron James continues to break records. The league also approaches the milestone of 14 million total points, expected to be reached around November 17. Naming trends, such as multiple players named Jordan, Nikola, and James, reflect broader cultural dynamics in the league.
